facts.text: This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad against an order dated September 25, 1957, dismissing a revision petition filed by the present appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad agai

Order 21, r. 50, of the Code of Civil Proce- dure reads as follows- 50.  1  Where a decree has been passed against a firm, execution may be granted-  a  against any property of the partnership  b  against any person who has appeared in his own name under rule 6 or rule 7 of Order XXX or who has admitted on the Pleadings that he is or who has been adjudged to be, a partner  c  against any person who has been individually served as a partner with a summons and has failed to appear Provided that nothing in this sub-rule shall be deemed to limit or otherwise affect the provisions of section 247 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872.

concepts.interpretation: The rule enables execution of decree against firm property or specific partners; under sub-rule 2, liability means primarily whether the person was a partner at the time cause of action accrued, or grounds like collusion or fraud, but not reopening the suit or inter-partner issues; leave granted if admits partnership absent special defences.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: duced as S 30. 30 and 0. 21, r. 50, of the Code of Civil Procedure. Order 30 deals with procedure in suits against firms in the firm name, and 0. 21,

concepts.unlisted_description: Execution of decrees against firms and partners

anchor.surface_text: provisions relating to suits against firms. Those provisions are contained in O. 30 of the Code, and must be viewed alongside to get the true meaning of the words. Order 30 and the provisions of r. 50 of O. 21 were taken from O. XL VII, a, of the Rules of the Supreme Court in England.

concepts.interpretation: Deals with suits against firms in firm name; summons service on firm or partners; partners served appear individually but suit continues in firm name; admitting partners defend on behalf of firm, denying partners cannot defend firm.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: awfully issued but the later rules which are more exhaustive, though they do number dispense with the forms of appearance, prescribe how the presence

anchor.surface_text: Provided that nothing in this sub-rule shall be deemed to limit or otherwise affect the provisions of section 247 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872.

issues.text: what kind of defences are open to such a person?

anchor.surface_text: the expression the liability of such person and this raises the question what kind of defences are open to such a person ? The learned Attorney- General has argued that the expression admits of a narrow construction, a wide construction and a construction which is in between the two.

issues.text: Whether the appellant, admitting he was a partner, is entitled to raise objections to the contract, reference to arbitration or the award in proceedings under O.21 r.50(2)

anchor.surface_text: In answer to the notice which was issued, the appellant, Seth Gambir Mal Pandiya, appeared and raised objections. He contended that he had not been served in the proceedings relating to the arbitration nor of the making and the filing of the award in Court. He also contended that Seth Tikam Chand, who had signed the contract containing the arbitration clause with the Mills, had no authority to enter into an agreement containing such a clause or to refer the dispute to arbitration on behalf of the other partners. He, therefore, maintained that the award was not binding on him.

issues.text: Whether 'liability' under O.21 r.50(2) admits of narrow, wide or middle construction

anchor.surface_text: The learned Attorney- General has argued that the expression admits of a narrow construction, a wide construction and a construction which is in between the two. The narrow construction, according to him, is that the only. issue to be tried is whether that person was a partner or held himself out to be one. The wide construction, according to him, is that the issue may take in all defences open to the partnership not raised in the suit and also all defences personal to that person to avoid his individual liability. Under the middle view, according to him, the Court is to try an issue relating to the personal liability of that person.

issues.text: Whether a partner not served in the suit can question the decree on grounds open if served, like invalid arbitration agreement

anchor.surface_text: Agarwala, J., held that although the decree passed against the firm was to be deemed to have been passed against all the individual partners thereof, it was binding proprio vigore only against the partnership property and personally against those persons, who are mentioned in cls. (b) and (c) of r. 50 (1), O. 21, and that the decree was not binding against the appellant, who had not been served in the suit and would be binding only when a summons was served upon him to appear under sub-r. (2) and his liability was determined.

arguments.claim: Correct view: liability means primarily partnership at cause accrual; plus collusion/fraud but not suit retrial or inter-partner issues; since appellant admits no special defence, leave granted

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the view expressed in these later cases is the correct one. As we have pointed out, O. 30 of the Code permits suits to be brought against firms.

holdings.text: The view expressed in these later cases [Bombay, Madras, Calcutta holding only partnership issue or collusion/fraud] is the correct one.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the view expressed in these later cases is the correct one. As we have pointed out, O. 30 of the Code permits suits to be brought against firms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.30 scheme allows suits in firm name; admitting partners defend firm only; English precedents and later Indian cases align limiting execution inquiry.

holdings.text: Proper meaning of 'liability' under O.21 r.50(2): primarily whether partner when cause of action accrued, but may question decree on collusion/fraud etc. not to retry suit or raise inter-partner issues.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, of the three constructions suggested by the learned Attorney-General, the widest meaning cannot be attributed to the word liability. The proper meaning thus is that primarily the question to try would be whether the person against whom the decree is sought to be executed was a partner of the firm, when the cause of action accrued, but he may question the decree on the ground of collusion, fraud or the like but so as not to have the suit tried over again or to raise issues between himself and his other partners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects wide construction allowing suit retrial; adopts middle but limited by O.30 scheme, English RSC precedents (Weir, Ellis, Davis), later Indian cases; distinguishes earlier wide views.

holdings.text: Once person admits partnership and has no special defence of collusion/fraud etc., Court must grant leave forthwith under O.21 r.50(2).

anchor.surface_text: Once he admits that he is a partner and has no special defence of collusion, fraud, etc. the Court must give leave forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent with scheme preventing reopening decree; protects firm decree execution while allowing narrow defences.

holdings.text: Appellant, admitting he was a partner, not entitled to raise objections to contract, arbitration reference, award, or lack of service in execution under O.21 r.50(2).

anchor.surface_text: No such question has been raised in this case, and the decision given by the High Court cannot be disturbed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above interpretation to facts: appellant admits partnership (f21); no collusion/fraud; objections go to suit merits/inter-partner authority.

holdings.text: High Court order dismissing revision correct; leave under O.21 r.50(2) properly granted to decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: No such question has been raised in this case, and the decision given by the High Court cannot be disturbed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds Beg J. and Mukherji J.; rejects Agarwala J.; applies limited scope of inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, of the three constructions suggested by the learned Attorney-General, the widest meaning cannot be attributed to the word liability. The proper meaning thus is that primarily the question to try would be whether the person against whom the decree is sought to be executed was a partner of the firm, when the cause of action accrued, but he may question the decree on the ground of collusion, fraud or the like but so as not to have the suit tried over again or to raise issues between himself and his other partners.
